Rita,

One could have a fairly simple representative democracy without any of the oddities we have incorporated into our republican system. You could have representation with each popular vote having an equal weight in selecting the representatives.

The Senate is specifically designed to represent states not people. The electoral college was specifically designed not to allow the popular election of the President, though it almost always does that now. The electoral college also has nothing to do with a representative democracy.

Look at John Boehner refusing to bring a clean CR and debt limit increase to the house floor, because he knows it will pass with a majority of the representatives in favor. He has the political power to stop a democratic decision by our representatives in this matter.

When Franklin characterized the new government as a republic after the convention, he was being precise in his terminology. Most of the delegates feared a real democracy.

I am afraid these are not just oddities of a representative democracy. We have a republican form of government, with some democratic features. It is important to get the meaning of words correct, as these distinction are important. (This is a philosophy oriented column and philosophers do like their meaning distinctions.)

By the way I am not being especially critical of our republic in this in the post. We may have exactly the government the majority wants.
Do you mean the Reagan who raised taxes and said that not raising the debt ceiling would be unthinkable?

Just the opposite Timothy....we haven't ignored Reagan-- we followed him....weakened govt, and regulation...cut taxes....congress has been run by and for businesses....lobbyists increased hugely. That's why health care became unaffordable, even for many insured. Why medical bankruptcies devastated whole families, who had already lost jobs and home value, or racked up huge college debt. There were so many ways they could be hit.

It's the perfect scam for a democracy--convince voters to wait for trickle down, even as they watch more jobs being sent away. The lower earners forced to take on more tax burden relative to their incomes, enabling the rich to amass than in Reagan's time. And few politicians ran on programs to redress the theft of jobs, resources and revenue.

OECD data shows US middle class security and living standards below many industrialized countries. After their conservatives gain power, they don't go quite as far right as ours do. Even Thatcher said every citizen must have guaranteed medical care.

And when their progressives regain office, with publicly financed elections, they have ways of restoring more balance to the economy. Thus their wealth gap is not as wide as ours--they couldn't be pushed constantly rightward, into oligarchic power imbalance.

So they still have health care, lower cost education, unions, apprenticeship training, and no one is running to destroy these.

This is easy to Google--try it.

Actually Timmy is right. Reagan did increase economic growth. He was a military Keynesian who tripled the national debt from $1 to $3 trillion by the time he left office. All of that spending combined with his rich man's tax cuts drove GNP growth throughout his time as President.

I can't stand what he did and deplore how the growth and its benefits were achieved and distributed - unnecessary, overpriced weapons systems and massive tax cuts for the rich - but there's no denying that the economy grew at a fairly decent clip after the 1982 recession. And to be fair the weapons we bought did come in handy in 1991 when we rented out the army to Saudi Arabia during Gulf War I.

By the way, the reason why we got into the 1982 recession to begin with was because the first Reagan budget was such a god-awful mess. It's what prompted Paul Volcker to drive up short terms interest rates to 20%.

What would Ronald Reagan do?

The answer to that question is the solution to our current economic and social problems.

Long ago he told us "government is not the solution but the problem." We ignored his advice and now suffer the consequencs.

President Reagan also said the way to create jobs and restore prosperity is to get government out of the way, unleash the American businessman, and cut taxes. We ignored that advice too. You've seen the results.

Under President Reagan our country flourished. It can again. The choice is ours.

Best of two worlds. I have also posted today This One's For Martha at my blog as my thanks to yet another Times reader who mailed me.

Larry Only-NeverInSweden.blogspot.com

The Tea Party, the 1%, the denial of scientific findings, the absence of Universal Health Care, the absence of voting at the 90% level, and the impact of Citizens United are among the first things that come to mind for this 81 year old American living in Sweden.

Add to that the daily displays of racism and a system of officially dividing people up into "races", a system founded in the eternal beliefs that only one "race" can be best.

These are the exceptionalisms of America that I am asked to explain to friends born in Sweden, Iran, Eritrea, and more. I cannot. Explaining these conditions is just as difficult as finding ways to satisfactorily comment on the American condition in the New York Times comment sections.

Still, one must try, even when it is not even midnight yesterday in my New England, USA.

Larry Lundgren Only-NeverInSweden.blogspot.com

This opens up the question are experts being both individually and collectively stupid in many other areas. I think they are.

One obscure example is the evolution of crocodilians. The biologists kept discovering that crocodilians have characteristics that only warm blooded animals have. There response was isn't that amazing. It took for ever for them to figure out the obvious crocodilians are cold blooded animals that are decended from warm blooded animals.

The first time they discovered that crocodilians have a characteristic normally only found in warm blooded animals they should have suspected this, the second time they should have said it was highly provible, etc. but they kept saying it is amazing.

If you have an idea that you think is strongly supported by the evidence and the experts can not touch it with evidence or reasoning, do not let their obstenance deter you. Paul has shown over and over the amazing ability of the experts to be both individually and collectively stupid.

We are all just talking apes barely intelligent enough to invent agriculture, and or civilization. Even the expers are human.

Your mentioning of the anniversary date got me to thinking about where we are, in tracking the Great Recession, to where were were at this point in the Great Depression.

The implosion occurred in autumn (October) 1929. A lot of the really bad stuff did not occur until years later. The banking crisis at the beginning of Roosevelt's administration was not until Winter (early) 1933 - three years later.

Likewise, the political fall out from 1929 did not happened immediately. The drift to radicalism didn't occur immediately. I think the Nazi's didn't get more than a hundred people into the Reichstag until well into 1931, and wasn't a pluralistic force until 1932. Only at the end of 1932, when they power was already waining, were they able to muscle in on the big show, with Hitler becoming Chancellor only in January 1933, two months before Roosevelt himself moved into the Whitehouse.

Radicalization of our politics began only in 2010. But the political crisis is only now hitting us. So, we are at the 5 year mark - fully 2 years behind schedule. Perhaps the automatic stabilizers (unemployment insurance, snap, social security, and the limited stimulus) slowed the process down.

Had the recession occurred a year earlier, Clinton might have won the nomination on the strength of the Clinton prosperity in the 1990s. Obama had no credentials, and worse, little knowledge in economics. Making matters worse was his naivete towards his opposition, something Clinton did not suffer from.

It is your post that is misleading. Regarding the threat of a downgrade, that was a fact that happened today. The warning was issued precisely because the rating agency is worried that congress may not allow borrowing to ensure continued liquidity.

Regarding default, the only ambiguity is when. You are incorrect. The US pays all it's bills as they come due. To prioritize payments would be a change in policy and could, in fact be illegal. Furthermore, even if we managed to pay the interest on the debt, we would still be in default on other legally binding obligations.

Finally, the continuing government shutdown is costing us money. What is propaganda is the idea that harming liquidity would not be seriously harmful to our credibility and the world economy.

The characterization of the current situation as a "crisis" is a misnomer. A crisis is a situation which arises through forces which are in no one's control, which comes to a critical point, and one way or another, is resolved. From what I am reading, the shutdown and default did not "happen," they were planned over several months, with deliberate action taken in the House to forestall any corrective measures which might be brought by the Speaker of the House. So how are we to judge the actions of congressmen who have carefully planned the shutdown and default of our government, and what course do we now take? I would think prosecution is in order.
